class_notes: Microorganisms living in and on our bodies outnumber our human cells. Sometimes considered "the forgotten organ" , this collection of bacteria, viruses, and single-cell eukaryotes is crucial for our health. We will examine the vital functions provided by the microbiome, as well as the conditions under which the microbiome is associated with disease. Areas of focus will include obesity, insulin resistance, inflammatory bowel disease, asthma, antibiotic resistance, and more. (Prerequisite: BIOL 142)
course_description: Trillions of symbiotic microbes composing the human microbiota are crucial for our health. We will examine the vital functions provided by the human microbiome, as well as its association with disease states, including obesity, insulin resistance, inflammatory bowel disease, asthma, and more.
prerequisites: BIOL 142 or BIOL_OX 142 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.
